title: cd2030 User Guide
text:
1 Introduction
Welcome to the cd2030 User Guide! This guide is designed to help you navigate the features and functionality of the cd2030 Shiny app. It provides step-by-step instructions for data loading, analysis, visualization, and report generation.

title: cd2030 User Guide
text:
1.1 About the App
The cd2030 Shiny App is a tool for analysing, visualizing, and reporting cd2030 vaccines data. Designed for researchers, policy makers, and program managers, it integrates various datasets including UN estimates, WUENIC estimates, survey data, and health facility data, to generate actionable insights and customizable reports.

title: cd2030 User Guide
text:
1.2 Key Features
The app offers a range features to streamline your data analysis workflow:

Data Integration: Easily upload and manage data from multiple sources. Supported formats and specific instructions will be detailed in the “Data Input” section.
Dynamic Visualizations: Generate charts, tables, and summaries to explore trends and patterns.
Custom Annotations: Add notes and explanations directly within the app to enhance documentation and provide context for your analysis.
Report Generation: Create reports in various formats to suit your needs.

title: cd2030 User Guide
text:
1.3 Prerequisites
Before using the app, ensure you have the following:

Software

R (version 4.0 or higher)
RStudio

R Packages: The required R packages will be automatically installed upon first launch if not already present. A full list of dependencies can be found in the “Installation” section.
Data: Access to necessary datasets

UN estimates
WUENIC estimates
Country-specific survey data
Health facility datasets for analysis.

title: cd2030 User Guide
text:
1.4 How to Use This Guide
This guide is structured to guide you through the app’s functionalities, from set-up to advanced usage. Use the sidebar to navigate to specific sections:

Installation: Detailed instructions for installing the app and its dependencies.
Data Input: Step-by-step guidance on loading and managing your data.
Data Analysis and Visualization: Comprehensive explanations of the available analytical tools and visualization options.
Report Generation: Instructions on creating reports.
Troubleshooting: Solutions to common issues and frequently asked questions.

title: cd2030 User Guide
text:
1.5 Acknowledgement
This app and guide were developed by the African Population and Health Research Centre (APHRC).

title: 2  Getting Started
text:
2.1 Prerequisites
This page will guide you through the steps required to install, set up, and launch the cd2030 Shiny App. Follow these instructions to ensure a smooth start.
Before using the app, ensure you have the following:

title: 2  Getting Started
text:
Software:

R (version 4.0 or higher recommended): Download it from CRAN.
RStudio (latest version recommended): Download it from RStudio.

Data Access: Ensure you have access to the necessary datasets:

UN estimates
WUENIC estimates
survey data

title: 2  Getting Started
text:
2.2 Installing the App
The cd2030 Shiny App is hosted on GitHub. To install it:

Open RStudio.
Install the pak package (if not already installed):


if (!require('pak')) install.packages("pak")

This package manager simplifies the app installation process.

Install the cd2030 app:


pak::pak("damurka/cd2030")

This will download and install the app on your system, along with all required packages.

title: 2  Getting Started
text:
2.3 Launching the App
Once installed, launch the app using the following commands:

library(cd2030)
dashboard()

The app will open in your default web browser, ready for use.








Figure 2.1: Launching the cd2030 Shiny App.

title: 2  Getting Started
text:
2.4 Next Steps
With the app installed and running, proceed to the App Features section to explore its functionality and workflows in detail.

title: 3  App Features
text:
3.1 Title Bar
This section details the main components of the cd2030 Shiny App interface: the Title Bar, Sidebar, and Main Panel (Body Content). Understanding these elements will help you navigate and use the app effectively.
The Title Bar, located at the top of the app, provides key information controls. The elements of the Title Bar, such as “Set Cache Directory/Save Cache” and “Download Report,” are only displayed after data has been loaded.

title: 3  App Features
text:
3.1.1 Key Elements of the Title Bar

Contextual Information: Displays the current analyssis context, such as the country of analysis (e.g., “Senegal - Countdown Analysis”).









Figure 3.1: The page title.






Cache Management

Set Cache Directory: This button allows you to specify a directory for saving intermediate results and progress.
Save Cache: This button allows you to save the progress of your analysis. This is useful for large analyses or for resuming a session later.










Figure 3.2: The cache management button.






Download Report: This button allows you to generate the final report. The available download formats are Word and PDF.









Figure 3.3: The cache management button.

title: 3  App Features
text:
3.2 Sidebar
The Sidebar, located on the left side of the app, provides navigation through the analysis workflow. The sections are arranged sequentially to guide you through the process.

3.2.1 Sidebar Navigation

Introduction: Provides a brief overview of the app’s purpose and functionality.









Figure 3.4: The Introduction page.






Load Data: Allows you to upload and manage your datasets (e.g. Health Facility Datasets, Master datasets, and cache file). It also allows you to download data diretly from the DHIS2 instance.









Figure 3.5: The data loading page.






Quality Checks: Provides tools for assessing data quality, include checks for consistency, completeness, and outliers. Subsections include:

Reporting Rate
Outlier Detection
Consistency Check
Data Completeness
Calculate Ratios
Overall Score










Figure 3.6: The data quality checks section.






Analysis Set-up: Allows you to configure the analysis by selecting the data sources (UN Estimates, WUENIC estimates, and survey data). It also allows you to map the sub-national survey and mapping data to the uploaded data.









Figure 3.7: The analysis setup page.






National and Sub-national Analysis: Provides tools for analysing coverage and equity at both the national and sub-national levels. This pages are only active after completing the “Analysis Set-up” section.









Figure 3.8: The analysis pages.

title: 3  App Features
text:
3.3 Main Panel(Body Content)
The main panel is the central workspace where the analysis result, visualizations, and interactive elements are displayed.

3.3.1 Key Elements of the Main Panel

Page Title: Displays the current module or analysis step (e.g., “Reporting Rate”).









Figure 3.9: The page title.






Action Buttons: Provides context-specific actions:

Generate Report: Downloads a report specific to the current page or analysis.
Add Notes: Allows you to add annotations and comments directly to the results or visualizations.
Get Help: Provides context-sensitive help and documentation for the current page.










Figure 3.10: The page actions.

title: Data Input
text:
Uploading Data
This page provides an introduction to two key functionalities of the app: Data Upload and DHIS2 Data Download. These tools enable efficient integration and preparation of the countdown data for analysis.
Easily upload the dataset formatted according to the Countdown Health Facility Data Format. This module includes

title: Data Input
text:
File Validation: Ensures your dataset complies with the required standards.
Supported formats: Accepts .xls, .xlsx, .dta and .rds files
Error Handling: Provides detailed feedback for resolving upload issues.

title: Data Input
text:
DHIS2 Data Download
Securely connect to DHIS2 servers to fetch health data for analysis. Key features include:

Customizable Period: Select a specific date range for the data.
Country Selection: Fetch data tailored to the selected country’s settings.
Secure Authentication: Your credentials are used securely and discarded after the session.

By following these guides, you can set up your data efficiently and ensure it is ready for detailed analysis in the app. Choose the appropriate section to get started:

4  Data Preparation
5  Upload Data
6  DHIS2 Download

title: 4  Data Preparation
text:
4.1 General Guidelines
This document outlines instructions for preparing data for the Country Analysis of Vaccine Indicators at the District Level. The data focuses on vaccines and will assess health service utilization at national and sub-national levels. Teams will extract and compile data from DHIS2 using a standardized template.
Follow these steps to ensure accurate and complete data preparation:

title: 4  Data Preparation
text:
Spreadsheet Structure: The template consists of the following worksheets:

Admin_data
Population_data
Reporting_completeness
Service_data_1
Service_data_2

Data Requirements: Extract monthly district-level data for at least three years.
Template Use: Do not alter the provided template’s structure or columns unless requested.
Consistency:

Ensure district names are uniform and listed in the same order across all worksheets.
Use the most recent district classification if available; otherwise, use the division covering the longest time span.

Data Extraction Methods: Data can be extracted using either of the following methods:

Manual: Export indicators from DHIS2 to a CSV file and compile them in the provided template.
API: Use the GFF-provided API for automated data extraction into a CSV file, then import it into the template.

title: 4  Data Preparation
text:
4.2 Worksheet Instructions
Adhere to worksheet-specific instructions to ensure accurate analysis and coverage estimates.

4.2.1 Admin_data

Enter administrative details (e.g., district names, codes).
This worksheet serves as the master list for districts; ensure complete consistency with other worksheets.



4.2.2 Population_data

Populate population estimates, including demographic breakdowns specified in the template.



4.2.3 Reporting_completeness

Record health facility reporting completeness (e.g., monthly report submission rates).



4.2.4 Service_data_1 and Service_data_2

Include service delivery indicators such as antenatal care or immunization coverage.
Ensure alignment with the template’s indicator requirements.

title: 4  Data Preparation
text:
4.3 Data Extraction Tools

4.3.1 Manual Extraction

Log in to DHIS2.
Export required indicators to a CSV file.
Compile the data into the appropriate worksheets.



4.3.2 API-Based Extraction

Access the GFF API with DHIS2 credentials.
Extract required indicators into a CSV file.
Import the CSV data into the template.
Coordinate with the Ministry of Health for API set-up if needed.

title: 5  Upload Data
text:
5.1 Understanding the Upload Process
This guide details how to upload data into the cd2030 app, ensuring compatibility with the Countdown Health Facility Data (HFD) Format.
The Upload Data module allows you to:

title: 5  Upload Data
text:
Upload health facility data structured according to the Countdown HFD Format.
Validate the uploaded file for format and data integrity.
Prepare the data for analysis within the app.

title: 5  Upload Data
text:
5.2 Supported File Formats
The app supports the following file types:

Excel Files (.xls, .xlsx): Primarily for raw or minimally processed data.
Stata Files (.dta): Processed and formatted data adhering to the HFD standard.
R Data Files (.rds): For pre-processed data, settings, or cached data.

title: 5  Upload Data
text:
5.3 Uploading Your File
Once your data is prepared:

Navigate to the Load Data section in the app’s sidebar.
Drag and Drop: Drag your file into the designated upload area.
Browse: Alternatively, click Browse to select the file from your computer.

The app will automatically validate the uploaded file.

Successful Upload: A confirmation message will appear: “Upload successful: Your file is ready for analysis.”
Upload Errors: If errors are detected, an error message will be displayed. See the “Troubleshooting Uploads” section below.

title: 5  Upload Data
text:
5.4 Troubleshooting Uploads
The following table lists common upload errors and their solutions:








Error Message
Cause
Solution




“Unsupported file format”
File type not supported.
Save your file as .xls, .xlsx, .dta, or .rds. .dta is the recommended format.


“The following required columns are missing from the data: [column names]”
Missing essential columns in the data.
Add the missing column(s) to your dataset and ensure their values are valid. Refer to the HFD Guidelines for required columns.


“The following sheets are missing: [sheet names]” (Primarily for Excel files)
Missing one or more required sheets in the Excel file.
Ensure all required sheets are present and conform to the template. If working with .dta or .rds files, this error should not occur.


“Sheet [Sheet Name] is empty” (Primarily for Excel files)
The sheet exists but contains no data.
Populate the sheet with valid data or remove the empty sheet. If working with .dta or .rds files, this error should not occur.


“Key Columns ‘[column names]’ missing in [Sheet Name]” (Primarily for Excel files)
A key column (district, year, or month) is missing from the specified sheet.
Add the missing column(s) to the sheet and ensure the data is structured correctly. If working with .dta or .rds files, this error should not occur.


“Column name ‘[column name]’ must not be duplicated. Use .name_repair to specify repair.”
Duplicate column names in the dataset.
Ensure all column names are unique. Rename or remove duplicate columns.


“Non-numeric values found in numeric column ‘[column name]’. These values have been coerced to NA.”
A numeric column contains non-numeric data.
Check the specified column for non-numeric values (e.g., text, special characters). Correct these values or convert them to missing values (NA) before uploading.

title: 5  Upload Data
text:
5.5 Data Validation within the App
The app performs the following validation checks during the upload process:

File Format Check: Confirms the file is in a supported format.
Sheet Presence Check (Excel only): Verifies that all required sheets are present.
Column Presence and Uniqueness Check: Ensures all required columns are present and unique.
Data Availability Check: Checks that required sheets/data are not empty and key columns are populated.
Data Type Validation: Checks that numeric columns contain valid numeric values. Non-numeric values will be coerced to NA.

title: 5  Upload Data
text:
5.6 How Errors Are Handled

If validation fails, the upload process stops, and an informative error message is displayed.
Consult the “Troubleshooting Uploads” section for solutions to common errors.

title: 6  DHIS2 Download
text:
6.1 Understanding the DHIS2 Download Process
This guide explains how to securely connect to DHIS2 using the cd2030 app and download relevant data.
The DHIS2 Download module allows you to:

title: 6  DHIS2 Download
text:
Securely connect to your DHIS2 instance.
Select the desired country and data period.
Download data in supported formats for use within the cd2030 app.

title: 6  DHIS2 Download
text:
6.2 Connecting to DHIS2
Follow these steps to establish a connection:

Enter Your Credentials: Provide your DHIS2 username and password in the respective fields.
Select a Country: Choose the relevant country from the drop-down menu. This selection is crucial as it determines the DHIS2 instance the app will connect to.
Set the Period: Define the date range for the data you wish to download using the Period selection tools. This allows you to specify the start and end dates for your data.
Click Login: Press the Login button to initiate the connection process. The app will attempt to authenticate your credentials with the specified DHIS2 server and download the relevant data.

title: 6  DHIS2 Download
text:
6.3 Downloading Data
Once a successful data download choose between the available download formats: - Download Master File: Downloads the data as a .dta (Stata) file. - Download Excel File: Downloads the data as a .xlsx (Excel) file.

title: 6  DHIS2 Download
text:
6.4 Security and Privacy
The cd2030 app prioritizes the security and privacy of your DHIS2 credentials:

Temporary Credentials: Your DHIS2 username and password are used only temporarily during the current session.
No Storage of Credentials: The app does not store your credentials persistently. Once the session ends or you close the app, all credential information is discarded.
Secure Connection: The app uses secure communication protocols (HTTPS) to connect to DHIS2 servers, protecting your data during transmission.
Open-Source Code: The app’s open-source nature allows for independent review of its code, ensuring transparency in how credentials and data are handled.

title: 6  DHIS2 Download
text:
6.5 Troubleshooting DHIS2 Connections and Downloads
The following table lists common errors and their solutions:








Error Message
Cause
Solution




“Error: Country must be selected”
No country was selected from the drop-down menu.
Select the appropriate country from the drop-down list.


“Error: Username must be provided”
The username field is empty.
Enter your DHIS2 username in the designated field.


“Error: Password must be provided”
The password field is empty.
Enter your DHIS2 password in the designated field.


“Download Error: Failed to retrieve user profile.”
There is an issue with the DHIS2 server, a network connectivity problem, incorrect credentials, or the selected country’s configuration within the app.

Verify your internet connection.
Double-check your DHIS2 username and password for typos.
Ensure the DHIS2 server is operational by accessing it through a web browser.
Confirm that you have access to the selected country’s DHIS2 instance.
If the problem persists, contact your DHIS2 administrator or the app’s support team.



“Download Error: Could not retrieve data for the specified period.”
No data exists on the DHIS2 server for the selected country and period, or the user lacks the necessary permissions.

Verify that data exists in DHIS2 for the chosen country and time period by checking DHIS2 directly.
Ensure your DHIS2 user account has the required permissions to access the data.

title: 7  Select Directory
text:
7.1 Steps to Use the Select Directory Feature
The Select Directory feature allows users to choose a folder on their computer for specific purposes, such as setting a cache directory. This guide explains how to use the directory selector efficiently.

title: 7  Select Directory
text:
7.1.1 Open the Directory Selector

Click the button labelled “Set Cache Directory” or any other action that opens the directory selector.
A window will appear, allowing you to browse your computer’s file system.









Figure 7.1: The select directory dialog.







7.1.2 Select a Drive (if needed)

Use the top-right drop-down menu labelled with the current drive (e.g., C:) to select a different drive.
Click the drop-down arrow and choose the drive where the desired folder is located.



7.1.3 Navigate Through the File System

Use the left-hand panel to browse available folders.
Expand a folder by clicking the small triangle next to its name.
Scroll as needed to view more directories.



7.1.4 Sort Content (Optional)

Use the “Sort Content” button to organize the folders alphabetically or by other criteria, if available.



7.1.5 Select a Folder

Click on the desired folder to highlight it.
Click the “Select” button at the bottom-right corner of the window to confirm your choice.



7.1.6 Verify Your Selection

Once the folder is selected, the application will confirm the operation with a message (e.g., “Cache directory set successfully”).

title: 7  Select Directory
text:
7.2 Best Practices

Ensure Folder Permissions:

Make sure the folder has the appropriate read/write permissions for the application to access or save files.

Use a Dedicated Folder:

Create and use a specific folder (e.g., “Cache” or “App Data”) to keep files organized and prevent mixing unrelated data.

Avoid System Folders:

Refrain from selecting critical system directories (e.g., C:/Windows) to avoid accidental changes to sensitive files.

title: 7  Select Directory
text:
7.3 Common Use Cases

7.3.1 Setting a Cache Directory

Store temporary files generated by the application to enhance performance by reusing cached data.

title: 8  Analysis Setup
text:
8.1 Setup National Rates
The Analysis Set-up feature allows users to configure national rates and upload necessary survey data to facilitate analysis. This guide provides a step-by-step explanation of how to set up national rates and upload survey data using the interface. Please note that file uploads are mandatory to proceed with any analysis beyond the set-up phase.
The Set-up National Rates section enables you to input key national-level indicators. Follow these steps to configure them:

title: 8  Analysis Setup
text:
8.1.1 Fields to Complete:

Neonatal Mortality Rate:

Enter the neonatal mortality rate (e.g., 0.025).

Post Neonatal Mortality Rate:

Specify the post-neonatal mortality rate (e.g., 0.024).

Twin Rate:

Input the rate of twin births (e.g., 0.015).

Pregnancy Loss:

Provide the rate of pregnancy loss (e.g., 0.03).

Still Birth Rate:

Enter the stillbirth rate (e.g., 0.02).

ANC1 to Penta1 Mortality Rate:

Include the ANC1 to Penta1 mortality rate (e.g., 0.025).

ANC1 Survey:

Input the ANC1 survey coverage percentage (e.g., 98).

Penta1 Survey:

Provide the Penta1 survey coverage percentage (e.g., 97).




8.1.2 Steps:

Enter the appropriate values for each field.
Ensure accuracy as these rates are crucial for subsequent analyses.

title: 8  Analysis Setup
text:
8.2 Upload Survey Data
The Upload Survey Data section allows you to upload necessary datasets for analysis. It supports files in .dta format. Follow the instructions below:

8.2.1 Upload UN Estimates Data

Click on “Browse or Drop…” under the Upload UN Estimates data section.
Select the file containing UN estimates data in .dta format.
Wait for the upload confirmation message.



8.2.2 Upload WUENIC Estimates

Similarly, click on “Browse or Drop…” under the Upload WUENIC estimates section.
Choose the file with WUENIC data in .dta format.
Confirm the upload completion.



8.2.3 Configure Survey Folder

Click “Browse or Drop…” under the Survey Folder section.
Navigate to the folder containing your survey files.
Select the folder and verify the folder path.



8.2.4 Subnational Manual Data Mapping

Use the Map Survey Data button to map subnational survey data.
Use the Map Mapping Data button to map shapefile data

title: 8  Analysis Setup
text:
8.3 Manual Mapping of Survey Data
The Manual Mapping of Survey Data feature enables users to align survey data with subnational regions accurately. This is crucial for ensuring consistency across administrative regions.

8.3.1 Steps to Map Survey Data:

Open the Manual Mapping Window:

Click on the “Map Survey Data” button in the Subnational Manual Data Mapping section.










Figure 8.2: The Manual mapping of subantional survey data dialog.






Review the Regions:

The mapping window will display a list of survey regions (e.g., “DRS Dakar”, “DRS Diourbel”).
Each region corresponds to a dropdown menu for mapping.

Select Corresponding Regions:

For each region in the left column, select the appropriate mapped region from the dropdown menu on the right.
Ensure all regions are mapped correctly to avoid discrepancies.

Save the Mapping:

After completing the mapping for all regions, click the Save Mapping button to confirm your selections.
Ensure a confirmation message appears (e.g., “Mapping saved successfully”).

Verify the Mapping:

Reopen the mapping window if needed to verify that all regions are mapped correctly.




8.3.2 Notes:

Manual mapping is optional. If the survey regions already align with the required subnational structure, mapping can be skipped entirely.
However, if mapping is required, it must be completed fully. Partial mapping is not allowed.
Double-check each selection to ensure accuracy.



8.3.3 Mandatory for Analysis
Uploading all required files is essential. Without these files, you will not be able to proceed with:

Denominator Assessment
National Analysis
Subnational Analysis

Ensure all files are uploaded before initiating these steps.

title: 8  Analysis Setup
text:
8.4 Best Practices

Ensure Data Formats: Upload files in .dta format only, as other formats are not supported.
Organize Data: Maintain a structured folder with properly named files to avoid confusion during uploads.
Validate Inputs: Double-check all input values and uploaded files for accuracy.
Monitor Upload Status: Verify that all uploads show a success message before proceeding.

title: 8  Analysis Setup
text:
8.5 Troubleshooting

File Upload Issues:

Ensure the file is in .dta format.
Confirm that the file path is accessible.

Incorrect Rates:

If you entered incorrect rates, re-enter the values and save them.

Survey Folder Not Set:

Ensure the folder exists and has proper permissions.
Retry selecting the folder if the issue persists.

title: 9  Documentation
text:
9.1 Steps to Add Notes
This feature allows users to document observations, interpretations, or additional information related to specific objects within the analysis. This guide provides a detailed explanation of how to add notes for various objects in the interface.

title: 9  Documentation
text:
9.1.1 Open the Add Notes Dialog

Navigate to the relevant section of the analysis (e.g., National Coverage).
Click the “Add Notes” button to open the Document Page dialog.



9.1.2 Select the Object to Document

In the dropdown menu labelled “Select object to document”, choose the object for which you want to add notes. Examples include: Measles 1, Penta 3, Penta1 to Penta3 Dropout e.t.c.



9.1.3 Enter Notes

In the text box write your notes.

Include any observations, interpretations, or relevant comments regarding the selected object.
Notes can include data trends, potential discrepancies, or contextual explanations.




9.1.4 Save the Notes

Click the “Save” button to save your notes.
Ensure a confirmation message appears indicating that the notes have been successfully saved.

title: 9  Documentation
text:
9.2 Best Practices for Notes

Be Specific: Write detailed and clear notes that directly relate to the selected object.
Use Context: Include explanations for data trends or deviations to assist in later review.
Organize Content: Use bullet points or short paragraphs for better readability.
Update as Needed: Edit and revise notes as new observations or data become available.

title: 9  Documentation
text:
9.3 Troubleshooting

Object Not Listed:

Ensure the object you want to document is part of the current analysis.

Notes Not Saved:

Verify that the dialog was not closed before clicking “Save”.
Retry saving the notes if an error occurs.

Notes Not Visible:

Check the saved location or return to the dialog to confirm the notes.

title: 10  Report Generation
text:
10.1 Steps to Generate a Report
The Report Generation feature allows users to create and download customized reports based on the analysis results. This guide outlines the steps for selecting a format, generating, and downloading a report using the interface.

title: 10  Report Generation
text:
10.1.1 Open the Download Options Dialog

Navigate to the relevant analysis section (e.g., National Coverage).
Click the “Generate Report” button to open the Download Options dialog.









Figure 10.1: The download options dialog.







10.1.2 Select the Report Format

In the dialog, choose a report format from the dropdown menu:

Options include Word or PDF formats.

Once the desired format is selected, proceed to the next step.



10.1.3 Generate the Report

Click the “Generate Report” button to initiate the report creation process.
A loading screen will appear.









Figure 10.2: The generate report loading screen.






Wait for the process to complete. Do not close the dialog during this step.



10.1.4 Download the Report

Once the report is successfully generated, a confirmation screen will appear.









Figure 10.3: The download report dialog






Click the “Download Report” button to save the file to your computer.
Alternatively, you can click “Dismiss” to close the dialog without downloading.

title: 10  Report Generation
text:
10.2 Best Practices

Select the Appropriate Format:

Choose a format that suits your intended use (e.g., Word for editing, PDF for sharing).

Ensure Analysis is Complete:

Verify that all necessary inputs and analyses are finalized before generating the report.

Save the Report:

Download and save the report immediately to avoid having to regenerate it later.

Avoid Interruptions:

Do not close the application or navigate away during the generation process.

title: 10  Report Generation
text:
10.3 Troubleshooting

Report Generation Fails:

Ensure all required inputs for the analysis are complete.
Retry generating the report.

Incorrect Format Selected:

Regenerate the report by selecting the correct format.

Report Not Downloaded:

If you missed downloading, repeat the generation process.

Loading Issues:

If the generation process takes too long, check your internet connection or system resources.
